questions.title: Yield Based Bond Convexity and Portfolio Properties
questions.question: For changes in yield-to-maturity, the convexity adjustment is most needed to account for the:

choices.B: bond price risk due to small changes in yield-to-maturity.
choices.C: non-linear relationship of bond prices and yield to maturity.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The convexity adjustment is a complementary risk measure to duration. It accounts for the second-order (non-linear) effect of yield changes on price. It is most useful for large yield changes, because duration provides a good approximation for small yield changes.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The convexity adjustment is a complementary risk measure to duration. It accounts for the second-order (non-linear) effect of yield changes on price. It is most useful for large yield changes, because duration provides a good approximation for small yield changes.

questions.title: Yield Based Bond Convexity and Portfolio Properties
questions.question: Given a 75 bps change in the yields-to-maturity for Bonds Y and Z, the convexity adjustment for Bond Z would be greater than the convexity adjustment of Bond Y:

choices.A: if the YTM change is positive.
choices.B: if the YTM change is negative.
choices.C: regardless of the direction of the change in YTM.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. Since the convexity adjustment uses the square of the change in yield, it is always positive regardless of the direction of the change in yield-to-maturity. As a result, the convexity adjustment for Bond Z will always be greater than the convexity adjustment for Bond Y, given the same change in yields-to-maturity.
questions.solution_html:

C is correct. Since the convexity adjustment uses the square of the change in yield, it is always positive regardless of the direction of the change in yield-to-maturity. questions.title: Yield Based Bond Convexity and Portfolio Properties
questions.question: The method of using weighted-average portfolio duration and convexity measures to assess price risk of a bond portfolio is best characterized as:

choices.B: being commonly used by portfolio managers.
choices.C: accommodating non-parallel shifts in the yield curve.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The weighted-average portfolio duration and convexity method is easy to calculate and apply in practice and is commonly used by portfolio managers to assess bond portfolio price risk. It does, however, implicitly assume parallel shifts in the yield curve. Using the weighted average of time to receipt of the aggregate cash flows is the theoretically correct method to calculate portfolio duration and convexity, but it is difficult to use in practice.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The weighted-average portfolio duration and convexity method is easy to calculate and apply in practice and is commonly used by portfolio managers to assess bond portfolio price risk. It does, however, implicitly assume parallel shifts in the yield curve. Using the weighted average of time to receipt of the aggregate cash flows is the theoretically correct method to calculate portfolio duration and convexity, but it is difficult to use in practice.
